head.title: Let's Try Again on Health Care

hedline.hl1: Let's Try Again on Health Care

abstract.p: John C Goodman letter backs proposal for refundable tax credits for people who buy their own health insurance (Sept 24 editorial)

block.p: Your support for refundable tax credits for people who buy their own health insurance is commendable (''Toward Universal Coverage,'' editorial, Sept. 24).
Your support for refundable tax credits for people who buy their own health insurance is commendable (''Toward Universal Coverage,'' editorial, Sept. 24).

Although the federal government ''spends'' $125 billion a year on tax subsidies for employer-provided insurance, most of the uninsured get virtually no tax relief when they buy insurance on their own.
But you are wrong to suppose that tax credits require a large budget outlay. We are spending billions of dollars on free care for the uninsured.
The sums we spend on ''safety net'' care could finance a generous tax subsidy without any new raid on projected budget surpluses.

Further, if we want to stem the rising tide of the numbers of uninsured, we must stop spending more on free care for the uninsured than we are willing to spend to encourage them to acquire private insurance instead.
JOHN C. GOODMAN President, National Center for Policy Analysis Dallas, Sept. 25, 2000
